text:
WORDS OPPOSITE IN MEANING (ANTONYMS)

Antonyms are words, which means the very opposite or nearly the opposite of each other in a particular sentence. Please take note that both synonyms and antonyms are often given in the Lexis and Structure section of UNN PUTME examination.

As we discussed earlier in the synonyms section, the issue of context is very important in determining the right opposite option. 

When we say context, we mean that the words or ideas expressed before and after the underlined word, provides us with the information we need to fully understand, evaluate or interpret the ideas or word in the passage.

Let’s take for example

Chimma was still single when she made her first Million.

In this sentence the opposite in meaning can’t be double because we are talking about her relationship status. So, a suitable option will be married.

So, to determine the meaning of a word in a sentence you must relate it with the words before and after it in that particular sentence. This can help you guess the answer when you don’t know the meaning of the word.

This is how the questions are presented - In question 9-11, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) in italics.

There are some rules that will help you to select the right options. 

 

Steps in selecting the option opposite in meaning

1. Always re-read the instruction at the top bar each time you enter a new question, most times due to the way the CBT platform is designed. Students normally assume they are still answering questions on options similar in meaning without knowing that they have entered antonyms. Be very careful.

2. Try to understand the central meaning of the given sentence as a whole.

2. Eliminate the obviously wrong answers, like the options similar in meaning to the word underlined.

3. Make a habit of reading all the options that are provided to you before answering the questions, to be sure you are not fooled by nearly correct choices. 

4. Select an answer that is opposite in meaning, and in context to the underlined or italicised word.

We have discovered from research that people that do well in English mastered previous UNN PUTME Past questions and Jamb Questions. So, we advise you to memorise all the examples in this app, 

 

UNN PUTME 2005/2006

1. The priest was invited to consecrate the new building.

A. destroy. B. abuse. C. tarnish. D. pollute

(D. Pollute; To make ceremonially or morally impure: defile)

 

2. A majority of those who sat for the last jamb examination are sanguine of success.

A. hopeful. B. unsure. C. pessimistic. D. disheartened

(C. Pessimistic; having or showing a lack of hope for the future: expecting bad things to happen)

 

3. When we woke up this morning, the sky was overcast.

A. cloudy. B. clear. C. shiny. D. brilliant

(B. Clear; Overcast: covered with clouds: darkened by clouds)

 

4. Enemies of progress covertly strife to undermine the efforts of this administration.

A. secretly. B. boldly. C. consistently. D. overtly

(D. Overt; easily seen: not secret or hidden)

 

PUME 2007/2008

5. The Military Governor upheld the decision of his cabinet.

A. Held up. B. Undercut. C. Maintained. D. Abolished. E. Reversed

(E. Reserved).

 

6. Chidi is naturally taciturn.

A. Friendly. B. Cheerful. C. Dumb. D. Lively. E. Reserved

(A. Friendly)

 

7. James is a disco-addict. He takes his student rather lightly.

A. Humorously. B. Gloomily. C. Tediously. D. Carefully. E. Seriously

(E. Seriously)

 

PUME UNN 2010/2011 (II)

8. The officer has commended the cordial relationship existing between the soldiers and the civilians.

A. disordered. B. confused. C. strained. D. unfortunate

(C. Strained).

 

9. Many foreign experts would like to establish in this country because the environment is congenial.

A. hostile. B. inhospitable. C. aggressive. D. offensive

(A. Hostile).

 

10. The new chairman has exhibited prudence in his handling of the revenue.

A. impudence. B. shabbiness. C. dishonesty. D. recklessness

(D. Recklessness)

 

11. There is no point dissipating energy on a useless argument.

A. destroying. B. marshalling. C. storing. D. conserving

(D. conserving)

 

12. There is much apathy among youths nowadays towards reading novels.

A. indecision. B. indifference. C. enthusiasm. D. inclination

(C. Enthusiasm).

 

PUME UNN 2011/2012

13. Indiscreet actions have always led to regrets. that is why one should be _____

A. judicious. B. frugal. C. circumspect. D. thrifty

(C. Circumspect).

 

14. His remark during the send-off party was very apt to serve as a warning.

A. inept. B. Foolish. C. ridiculous. D. silly

(A. Inept).

 

PUME UNN 2014/2015 (II)

15. The class prefect was one of the main actors of the occasion______.

A. critics. B. spectators. C. guests. D. performers

(B. Spectators).

 

16. The governor declined to give audience to the journalist.

A. ignored. B. accepted. C. forgot. D. rejected

(B. Accepted).

 

PUME UNN 2015/2016

17. The plebs can be found in every society of the world.

A. masses. B. elite. C. middle class. D. politicians

(B. Elite)

 

18. Oche entered the principal's office in a rather abrasive manner.

A. gentle. B. lackadaisical. C. rude. D. indifferent

(A. Gentle). 

 

JAMB EXPECTED QUESTIONS
 

Section 1

1. I am happy to inform you that your boys are conscientious

A. industrious. B. carefree. C. careful. D. corrupt

(carefree)

 

2. My father is a very prosperous businessman.

A. ungrateful. B. unscrupulous. C. unskilled. D. unsuccessful

(unsuccessful)

 

3. My hostess greeted her guest in a very relaxed manner

A. energetic. B. athletic. C. stiff. D. perplexed

(stiff)

 

4. Ayo takes his studies rather lightly

A. humorously. B. tediously. C. carefully. D. seriously

(seriously)

 

5. The doctor was very gentle with his patients in the examining room

A. harsh. B. rude. C. rough. D. unkind

(harsh)

 

6. The President took exception to the ignoble role the young man played in the matter

A. honourable. B. embarrassing. C dishonourable. D. extraordinary

(honourable)

 

7. The man who had been seriously ill was convalescing at a seaside resort --

A. regaining health. B. deteriorating in health. C. recuperating. D. relaxing

(deteriorating in health)

 

8. For millions of years, the world resources have remained boundless 

A. unlimited. B. scarce. C. indomitable. D. limited

(scarce)

 

9. The difference between the experimental procedures was imperceptible to me

A. negligible. B. significant. C. obvious. D. obscure

(Significant)

 

10. His anti-apathy to religion ideas makes him unpopular

A. remedy. B. Consciousness. C. hostility. D. receptiveness

(receptiveness)

 

11. The relationship between the couple has been frosty (a) amenable (b) fraudulent (c) frugal (d) cordial
(cordial)


12. The dressmaker unpicked the seam of the shirt (a) tore up (b) sewed up (c) threaded (d) picked up

(sewed up)
 

13. Some of my neighbours have an antipathy to dogs (a) enmity towards (b) alarm for (c) acronym (d) affection for

(affection for)



14. Chibuzor gave a curt nod and walked away (a) rude (b) polite (c) gentle (d) shocking

(polite)


15. The girl took a cursory glance at the letter and hid it (a) brief (b) sententious (c) lasting (d) concise

(lasting)
 

Section 2

16. The accused was eventually convicted (a) initially (b) finally (c) subsequently (d) consequently

(initially)



17. My niece has an unquenchable thirst for adventure stories (a) an illegitimate (b) a spurious (c) an inextinguishable (d) a reduced
 

(a reduced)


18. Musa is a gifted but erratic player (a) regular (b) strong (c) unstable (d) unpredictable

(regular)


19. The testimony of the witness was vague (a) real (b) factual (c) true (d) clear

(clear)

 

20. As a student, Isa tried communal living for a few years (a) shared (b) private (c) collective (d) general

(private)


21. The lamb is a feeble little animal (a) fat (b) weak (c) loving (d) quite

weak

 

22. Adewale's arrival always triggers a media frenzy A. Violence. B. Agitation C. Calm D. Excitement.

(Calm)

 

23. She said, the experience was harrowing. A. Educating B. Frightening C. Pleasant D. Strange
(Pleasant)
 

24. The house was invaded by the young officers A. Set up B. Put down C. Defended D. built.

(Defended)

 

25. I like Adamu weird attitude. A.Buoyant  B. Peculiar C. Zestful D. normal. D. inglorious

(normal)

 

26. We travelled to an obscure little town A. rugged B. Distinguished C. Secluded D. inglorious

(Distinguished)

 

27. She is known for her bizarre dressing. A. Natural B. Weird C. Obsolete D. Odious

(Natural) 

 

28. Lami normally scurries around town A. Scampers B. Dashes C. Dawdles D. Scuttles

Dawdles

 

29. Sule’s poem is always explicit and compelling A. Exciting B. Clear C. Ambiguous D.Long.

Ambiguous

 

30. Usman smiled in a scornful way A. Respectful B. Derisive C. Sarcastic D. Deluded.

(Respectful)

 

Section 3

31. Alade is noted for his erratic behaviour. A. Fitful B. Bizarre C. Consistent D. Euphoric

(Consistent)

 

32. The priest knows Ochai as an abstainer A. Someone who never drinks alcohol B. Someone who holds onto his ideas C. Someone who reads a lot D. Someone who never cares about others
(Someone who never drinks alcohol)
 

33. Prolonged strike action debilitated the industry.
A. invigorated. B. isolated. C. weakened. D. destroyed

(invigorated)



34. One of the students bought a plagiarized copy of the book
A. a used. B. an original. C. a revised. D. an annotated

(an original)


35. The young girl was taken aback by her father's gift of a car.
A. shocked. B. unmoved. C. surprised. D. nonplussed
(unmoved)


36. Musa is a gifted but erratic player
A. strong. B. regular. C. unpredictable. D. unstable

(regular)


37. The lamp shades were translucent
A. opaque. B. interested. C. luminous. D. transparent

(Opaque)
 

38. My niece has an unquenchable thirst for adventure stories.
A. a spurious. B. an illegitimate. C. a reduced. D. an inextinguishable
(a reduced)


39. Some of my neighbours have an antipathy to dogs.
A. enmity towards. B. affection for. C. acronym for. D. alarm for

(affection for)

 

40. The testimony of the witness was vague.
A. disturbing. B. true. C. ambiguous. D. clear

(clear). 



41. As a student, Isa tried communal living for a few years
A. collective. B. general. C. shared. D. private.
(private)

 

42. Chibuzor gave a curt nod and walked away.
A. gentle. B. rude. C. polite. D. shocking.

(gentle)


43. The girl took a cursory glance at the letter and hid it.
A. sententious. B. concise. C. brief. D. lasting.
(lasting)


44. The relationship between the couple has been frosty.
A. fraudulent. B. cordial. C. amenable. D. frugal.
(cordial)


45. The Nobel laureate’s activity in the field of science is heinous.
A. indelible. B. laudable. C. deplorable. D. forgettable.
(laudable)


Section 4

46. The accused was eventually convicted.
A. initially. B. consequently. C. subsequently. D. finally.
(initially)


47. The plebs can be found in every society of the world.
A. masses. B. middle class. C. elite. D. politicians
(elite)


48. Everyone’s condition was appalling.
A. simple. B. cloudy. C. pleasant. D. complex
(pleasant)


49. The man’s mordant wit is apparent to the entire village.
A. Kind. B. scathing. C. caustic. D. withering
(withering)


50. The war against malaria keeps waxing.
A. happening. B. decreasing. C. increasing. D. wavering
(wavering)


51. The soldiers tried in their dogged defence of the city.
A. indifferent. B. strong. C. miserable. D. classical

(Indifferent)


52. We were shocked by the news that he had lost the money.
(a) astonished (b) disconcerted (c) unconcerned (d) surprised
(disconcerted)


53. The principal was advised to be flexible on critical issues.
(a) livid (b) cautious (c) evasive (d) rigid
(rigid)


54. Dupe was promoted for her efficiency.
(a) ability (b) incompetence (c) inconsistency (d) rudeness

(incompetence)


55. Election process often become volatile.
(a) calm (b) strange (c) sudden (d) latent
(calm)

 

56. Oche entered the principal’s office in a rather abrasive manner.
(a) gentle (b) rude (c) lackadaisical (d) indifferent
(gentle)


57. His gift to the poor was always infinitesimal.
(a) large (b) small (c) supportive (d) shameful
(large)
 

58. The economist concluded that several factors have been adduced to explain the fall in the birth rate. (a) affirmed (b) diffused (c) mentioned (d) refuted
(refuted)


59. The presidential system is an antidote to some political ailments.
(a) an answer (b) a reply (c) an injury (d) an obstacle
(an obstacle)


60. Ola thought that her father was very callous.
(a) parlous (b) compassionate (c) wicked (d) cheerful
(compassionate)


61. He was very much respected, though he had no temporal power.
(a) spiritual (b) mundane (c) permanent (d) ephemeral
(spiritual)


62. The way the worship was organized was rather hit-and-miss.
(a) systematic (b) hasty (c) slow (d) funny
(systematic)


63. The warring communities were coerced into negotiation a settlement
(a) driven (b) compelled (c) persuaded (d) pressured
(persuaded)
 

64. His father served as a mercenary in the army
(a) preacher (b) regular (c) recruit (d) officer
(regular)


65. Jummai is cruel to her husband
(a) harsh (b) brutal (c) passionate (d) ferocious
(passionate)


66. The teacher who beat the student was treated with mercy
(a) disrespect (b) contempt (c) vengeance (d) kindness
(vengeance)


Section 5

67. His wife hated his garrulous attitude.
(a) outspoken (b) unfriendly. (c) reticent (d) thoughtful
(reticent)


68. Agoshito is a callow youth; said the teacher
(a) An ignorant. (b) An experience (c) An idle (d) An organized
(An experience)


69. What you are asking me to do is a herculean task
(a) a strenuous (b) a demanding (c) a lovely (d) an easy

(an easy)

70. Nkechi was a novice when she was first employed
(a) manager (b) clerk (c) supervisor (d) professional
(professional)


71. I do not trust him ‘he said, in a rare moment of candour
(a) reproach (b) dishonesty (c) frankness (d) fairness
(dishonesty)


72. Mrs Akunilo looks anaemic today
(a) strange (b) sick (c) weak (d) strong
(strong)


73. It is inconceivable that the sun shone in the night
(a) credible (b) unthinkable (c) impossible (d) contestable
(credible)


74. She only gives a superficial impression of warmth and friendliness
(a) a strong (b) a fake (c) a deep (d) an unrealistic
(a deep)


75. As a prudent businessman, Adayi does not leave anything to chance
(a) A frugal (b) Shrewd (c) careless (d) unsuccessful
(careless)


76. His antipathy affected the growth of his business
(a) hatred (b) receptiveness (c) loyalty (d) hostility
(receptiveness)


77. Okonkwo’s lethal right foot did the magic in the football match
(a) Weak (b) wicked (c) fat (d) harmless
(Weak)
 

78. I am optimistic about the interview though it was a mind-bending exercise
A. An enervating B. A debilitating C. A difficult D. An easy
(An easy)


79. The trader was amused by the cut-throat rush for the goods
A. Worrisome B. Strange C. Lacklustre D. Mad
(Lacklustre)


80. The teacher said that Ali’s essay was full of many redundant details
A. Unexplained B. Strange C. Necessary D. Useful
(Necessary)


81. His father surmounted the myriad of obstacles on his way
A. Most B. Few C. All D. Many
(Few )

Section 6

82. Her ingenuous smile drew our attention
A. Witty B. Naïve C. Clever D. Arrogant
(Arrogant)


83. Ndeni gave a flawless speech at the party
A. A wonderful B. A careless C. An interesting D. An imperfect
(An imperfect)


84. Beneath Ado’s guff exterior, he’s really very kind-hearted
A. Nice B. Harsh C. Rough D. Gentle
(Nice)


85. The captain says sports is being debased by commercial sponsorship
86. A. Localized B. Perverted C. Elevated D. Overvalued
(Elevated)


87. Governing a country is not always as straightforward as people sometimes imagine
A. Complicated B. Troublesome C.  Untoward D. Irksome
(Complicated)


88. The crowd was very receptive to the speaker’s suggestion
A. Disobedient B. Repellent C. Alert D. Hostile
(Hostile)


89. There was a general acquiescence on the new drug law
A. Resistance B. Discrepancy C. Compromise D. Agreement
(Resistance)


90. Aisha seems to feel ambivalent about her future
A. Decisive B. Anxious C. Ambitious D. Inconsiderate
(Decisive)


91. The report of the committee contained a plethora of details
A. Shortage B. Simplicity C. Multitude D. Spectrum
(Shortage)


92. The weather was still very heavy and sultry
A. Wintry and shadowy B. Cold and friendly C. Cloudy and thundery D. Hot and uncomfortable
(Cold and friendly)


93. Ada gave her husband a look that made words superfluous A. Redundant B. Spurious C. Unnecessary D. Scanty
(Scanty)
